title: Climate Change and Geohazards in the Swiss Alps
text:
Rockfalls, Landslides, Glacial lake outburst floods, debris flows and many more geomorphic hazards put human lives and settlements in danger. Switzerland is a densely populated country with many mountaineous areas in the Alps. Climate Change heavily influences alpine environments, especcially the cryosphere. Therefore the hole geomorphodynamic of the alps is changing rapidly, which brings new challenges for both adaption and mitigation strategies.
Speaking about hazards, the hazard itself, like debris flows and landslides must be understood, in terms of their triggering processes and their propagation mechanisms. Building on that the impact of the modelled climate change can be estimated, which will then helps to identify, which strategies can be choosen to cope with those hazards. Further information and data is accessible on the following webpages: Em-Dat Database. Information regarding policy and mitigation strategies can be found on: UNDRR PreventionWeb.

Rockfalls
A rockfall is vertical rapid movement of bedrock as a consequence of weathering processes in consolidated rockwalls. Mostly diurnal cycles of temperature and insulation causes rockfalls. Important factors contributing to their genesis are local geology, topography, aspect, steepnees and altitude of the slope (Zepp 2023).

Engineering Solutions
Technical solutions are mostly used for monitoring, modelling and risk estimation of natural hazards. Many techniques are used from ground based RADAR sensing, satellite remote sensing, LiDAR, Air borne optical and LiDAR measrument, to borehole measurments of temperatures in permafrost areas and field campaigns (Camera 2023; Noetzli 2024; Seiz 2011; Gischig 2010, BAFU 2020).
As Switzerland does not operate optical satellites itself, it is cooperating with the ESA and seeks to deepen this cooperation, to use satellite imagery (Camera 2023). Worldwide exceptional is the PERMOS network, consisting of 14 boreholes in the swiss alps, it is reporting permafrost temperatures since 25 years and helps to ground truth modelling and remote sensing data (Noetzli et al. 2021; Seiz 2911; PERMOS 2025).

title: Climate Change and Geohazards in the Swiss Alps
text:
Organisational Solutions
As a federal state, Switzerland is based on subsidence, so therefore mostly local authorities are in charge. Cantons and the federal state, only step in, when neccesary. In terms of spatial planning, knowledge about hazard prone areas are mandatory to be used and can stop further develop.
Learning from each other and sharing data is right at the core of the Swiss strategy. Therefore multiple platforms, such as the public available and easy to understand Natural Hazards portal or the GIN-portal with live data for specialists , exist. To further enhance knowledge transfer among stakeholders, the PLANAT community instituionally provides a platform for universities, engineering companies, reinsurance companies, different local, cantonal and federal authorities to exchange their knowledge.
